718553f-a.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718553f-a.text:
Centre Street (left) &. Park Row (right), northward from
peint on Nassau ftreet and across Frankfort Street.
The Tryon Row Buildings were replaced by the Stats Ceitung
Building, and which in turn was replaced by the Punicipal
Building. Note the spire of the St. Andrews R. C. Church
across same. On the right is the 5 story building that
housed Tammany Hall until it's acouisition in 1868 by the
Sun. This structure is at the S. E. corner of Nassau and
Frankfort Street's. The dark building beyond is Frenchs
Hotel (Pulitzer Building site).
Early 1860's
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street
Gift of the Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICHTE UNENOwN
718553f-a.folder: Centre Street & Park Row, Manhattan, NY

722439f.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street
722439f.text:
Park Row, east side, south from and including Spruce 3treot, to
and including Broadway. Also shown is Nassau Street, east side, south
from and including Spruce, to and including Fulton Streets. The view
shows the New York Times Building, at the intersection of Park Pow,
and Sassau Street, and the rear of the General Post Office on Mail
Street. In the foreground is seen a portion of City Hall Park, while
in the background, and at the termination of Park Row, is seen St. Paul's
Protestant Episcopal Chapel.
About 1870.
Brown Brothers.
Niea ~ w50
722439f.folder: Park Row & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

721888f.title: Manhattan: Nassau Street - Spruce Street
721888f.text:
Nassau Street, east side, from Spruce (right) to Prank-
fort (left) Street's, showing structures lining Printing
House Square, as photographed from City Hall Park. The
Tribune Building is the dominant feature with the clock
tower. On the lert is Frenchs Hotel. This will be re-
placed shortly with the Pulitzer (World) Building. The
5 story Sun Building sepsrates these items. Cn the mar-
gins, left and right respectively, are the City Hall, and
the Times Building (under construction).
"inter 1888-9
Thru New York Historical Society
721888f.folder: Nassau Street & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

722448f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Frankfort Street
722448f-a.folder: Park Row & Frankfort Street, Manhattan, NY

722449f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Frankfort Street
722449f-a.text:
Park Row, east side, at Frankfort Street, as seen from across City
Hall Park. The view shows a portion of the City Hall on the right
and the Pulitzer Building (also known as the "7orld" Building.) in the
background.
About 1899.
Ewing Galloway.

722449f-a.folder: Park Row & Frankfort Street, Manhattan, NY

721887f-a.title: Manhattan: Nassau Street - Spruce Street
721887f-a.text:
Nassau Street, east side, trom Spruce (right) to Frank-
Tort (left) Streets, showing the buildings identified
with this locale, Printing House Scuare. From right to
left, these are, the Times Building (erected 1888), the
Tribune Building (erected 187O's), the Sun Building (
Chas. A. Dana became editor in 18bB and transfered here),
and the Pulitzer (World) Building (erected 1888-9).
At the left margin appears 6 portion oI the City Hall and
the Brooklyn Bridge train shed. The trees in the fore-
ground are in City Hall Park.
About 1891
Thru New York Historical Society
721887f-a.folder: Nassau Street & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

721884f-a.title: Manhattan: Nassau Street - Spruce Street
721884f-a.text:
Nassau Street, east side, at Spruce Street. The view also shows
teruce Street, south side, at Sassau Street. I the foreground is a
portion of Printing House Square, with a statue of Benjamin Franklin .
Oh the left is the old Tribune Building and the former Times Building
is on the right.
About 1905.
Brown Brothers.
721884f-a.folder: Nassau Street & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

722441f.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street
722441f.text:
Park Row, north from Spruce Street and showing prominently the
Municipal Building (Centre Street and Park Row) under constru:tion.
On the left is City Hall Park; a rear view of the 5-story City Court
and the new Hall of Records. The enclosed bridge structure provided
access to the Brooklyn Bridge and its transportation facilities.
About 1910
Ewing Galloway
722441f.folder: Park Row & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

718556f-a.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718556f-a.text:
Contre Street and Park Row convergence, northward across
Chambers Street, showing the Municipal Building under constreuction.
Park Row is on the right and has the "El" line there upon.
Chambers Street is at the left and separates the new Hall of Records
from the fire engine house in City Hall Park. Across the top are
two of Manhattan's great bridges, the Manhattan, and the Williams-
burg.
1912
Gift of Urbrock Collection
International News
718556f-a.folder: Centre Street & Park Row, Manhattan, NY

722458f.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street
722458f.folder: Park Row & Centre Street, Manhattan, NY

718549f-a.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718549f-a.text:
Centre Street, north from Park Row. On the west sid of Centre
Street, apnears the present Hall of Records. The Municial Building is
shovn on the right.
About 1925.
Brown Brothers.
718549f-a.folder: Centre Street & Park Row, Manhattan, NY

722446f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Frankfort Street
722446f-a.text:
Park Row, east side, north from and including Frankfort Street, to
and including The Brooklyn Bridge Approach, near North William Street.
Also shown is Nassau Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Frankfort
Street. In the foreground, is shown a portion of City Hall Park, with
a part of the City Hall. The Municipal Building is seen towering above
the Second and Third Aves., Elevated Brooklyn Bridge Station extension.
Adjoining said station on the south, is the Pulitzer Building, (also known
as the "world Building"). A portion of the Tribune Building, is shown on
the extreme right.
About 1925.
722446f-a.folder: Park Row & Frankfort Street, Manhattan, NY

722440f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street
722440f-a.text:
Park Row, north from and including Spruce Street. The view shows
(from left to right), the N. Y. City Hall, Hall of Records, the Municipal
Building, the N. Y. Herold Building, the Pulitzer (Aorld) Building, Tribune
Building and the Potter(Times) Building. Bridge shown in the foreground,
across Park Row, is an extension from the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the
Second and Third Aves., Elevated Lines.
About 1927.
New York Edison Co.  Yneo w G5
722440f-a.folder: Park Row & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

721886f-a.title: Manhattan: Nassau Street - Spruce Street
721886f-a.text:
Nassau Street, east side, north from but not including Spruce, to
and includin; Frankfort Stroets. Also shown is Park Row, east side,
north from Spruce Street, to and including the Brooklyn Bridge Approach,
(near North William Street). The view shows the Pulitzer (Wbrld)
Puilding adjoining the 3ridge Approach, with a statue of Benjamin Franklin
in the foreground ac the intersection of Nassau Street and Park Row.
June 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
721886f-a.folder: Nassau Street & Spruce Street, Manhattan, NY

722450f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Frankfort Street
722450f-a.text:
Park Row, east side, at Fankfort Street, as seen from across
City Hall Park. The view shows a portion of the City Hall on the
right and the Pulitzer Building (also known as the "World" Euilding) in
the background.
June 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
722450f-a.folder: Park Row & Frankfort Street, Manhattan, NY

722438f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street
722438f-a.text:
Park Row, east side, south from and including Spruce Street, to but
not including Broadway. Also shown is Nassau Street, west side, south
from and including Spruce Street. The view is taken from the Municipal
Puilding, and shows a portion of City Hall Park in the foreground.
June 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

722442f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street
722442f-a.text:

Park. The view shows a portion of the General Post Office on the right.
June 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

718550f-a.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718550f-a.text:
Centre Street, at Park Row, showing prominently the Municipal B
and the Manhattan Approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. In the foregrc
appears the northeastern corner of City Hall Park with the Hall of
opposite (left foreground). Across the East River looms the Brook
shore.
1936.
W.P.a. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

718959f-a.title: Manhattan: Frankfort Street - Park Row
718959f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view of the Citk Hall, as seen from Frankfort Street
and viewing westward across Park Row. I1 the background appear the Postal
Telegraph & Cable and the Home Life Insurance Company buildings; both on
Broadway, at and adjoining the N.e4. corner of Murray Street. This is a
set consisting of two views.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

Centre Street, north from Park Row.

718548f-b.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718548f-b.text:
Centre Street & Park Row (convergence), showing the Muni-
cipal Building under construction in View 1, and completed
in View 2. The photographers vantage point in both instan-
ces is City Hall Park. Note the enclosed over-pass to the
Brooklyn Bridge at the right.
No. 1: 1911
2: Sept., 1914
Ceorge L. Balgue

718551f-a.title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row
718551f-a.text:
Centre Street (left) and Perk Row, northward, showing the
Staats 2eitung Building. Upon this site rose the present Muni-
cipal Building. On the left is the fire enginr house in City
Hall Park, separated by Chambers Street from the row of build-
ings, upon which site the Hall of Records was erected. Park
Row on the right, appears prior to the erection of tho Third
Avenue 'E1.'
1870

722445f-b.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Frankfort Street
722445f-b.text:
(1)
Park Row, north from Frankfort Street, to the Brooklyn Bridge.
The view shows the Brooklyn Bridge Extension of the Second and Third
Avenue Elevated, over Park Row, to City Hall Park. Prominent in the
background, is the Municipal Building. On the right appears the
World (Pulitzer) Building.
April 18, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view.
April 18, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same area subsequent to the removal of the aforementioned
pedestrian over-approach to the Bridge. Remaining is the "El" station
and the train shed from which formerly all Brooklyn traffic started.
Beyond same is the New York Herald building and statuette on North
William Street. Note the automobile entrance to the Bridge adjoining
the World Building.
July 4, 1938.
722445f-b.folder: Park Row & Frankfort Street, Manhattan, NY
